TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE , DATE and DATE respectively and live in PERSON .

It was also established that the abdominal injury could have resulted from DATE on to a blunt object , such as a kerb or a concrete pole . Other injuries found on his arms , legs and buttocks could have resulted from his body being dragged .

The applicants have provided no documents concerning the course of the investigation , maintaining that they had been denied access to the case file and any meaningful opportunity to participate in the proceedings , regardless of their repeated complaints to various authorities , including ORG . By way of response , ORG kept forwarding their complaints to ORG , which assured the applicants , without providing any details , that the criminal proceedings were well under way . On several occasions the first applicant requested a meeting with the employees of ORG to discuss the progress of the case ; however , her requests were not accommodated .

On DATE the first applicant lodged a complaint with ORG of GPE , seeking to oblige ORG to ensure meaningful monitoring of the proceedings and to address omissions by the local authorities . CARDINAL . On DATE the court dismissed this claim . It found , in particular , that the investigation was pending , the necessary investigative measures were under way , the persons responsible for inflicting injuries on her son had not yet been identified , ORG was monitoring the proceedings and ORG had referred the applicants ' complaints to the local prosecutorial authorities for reacting . CARDINAL . According to the ORG 's submissions , the expert assessment of DATE established that PERSON death had been directly caused by the internal abdominal injury and acute haemorrhage . These injuries could have resulted from DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE a further expert assessment confirmed the results of the previous assessments .

CARDINAL . On DATE a further expert assessment established that the injury had been inflicted by the impact , of considerable force , of a blunt object with limited contact surface , possibly a booted foot , hitting the applicant 's abdomen at an acute angle . This injury could not have resulted from a simple fall on to a flat or convex surface .
CARDINAL . On DATE a further expert assessment concluded that the injury could have been inflicted in the circumstances described by the first applicant .
